abstract: Former Yukos Oil executives, shareholders and creditors are taking their case to the European Court of Human Rights Thursday, in Strasbourg, France, claiming they are owed $98 billion by the Russian government because their rights to property and a fair trial were violated.
snippet: Former Yukos Oil executives, shareholders and creditors are taking their case to the European Court of Human Rights Thursday, in Strasbourg, France, claiming they are owed $98 billion by the Russian government because their rights to property and ...
lead_paragraph: Yukos Oil had a poor track record defending its rights in Russian courts. Once the largest company in the country, it fell out of favor with the government of Vladimir V. Putin, then the president, in 2003 and within four years had been bankrupted and sold at auction.

headline.main: European Court Ready to Hear Yukos Case
